page.text: This document is a Draft Initial Study/Mitigated Negative Declaration (IS/MND) for the City of San
Mateo Los Prados Park Turf Conversion Project (proposed project). The City of San Mateo is the
lead agency under the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) and is responsible for
ensuring CEQA compliance prior to approval of the proposed project.
P
ROJECT
S
UMMARY

OMMENT
The City intends to release this Draft IS/MND for the proposed project to agencies, organizations,
and interested persons for their review and comment. Reviewers should focus on the content
and accuracy of the Draft IS/MND in considering potential impacts on the environment.
The Draft IS/MND will be available for review on the City of San Mateo website at:

Main Library

page.text: The Draft IS/MND will be circulated for a 20-day review period. Persons responding should submit
their comments in writing. Written comments should be delivered to the City’s main office, at the
address listed below, by no later than 5:00 PM on Tuesday, January 6, 2015. Submittal of written
comments via e-mail is also acceptable. Comments submitted by e-mail should be sent to the
e-mail address listed below. Questions regarding this Draft IS/MND should be directed to Guido F.
Persicone, Associate Planner.
City of San Mateo, Planning Division
th
Avenue
San Mateo, CA 94403
Attn: Guido Persicone
E-mail: gpersicone@cityofsanmateo.org
Comments received during the 20-day review period will be incorporated into the Final IS/MND.
The Planning Commission will hold a public hearing on Tuesday, January 27, 2015 at 7:30 PM, for
the purpose of making a recommendation to the City Council on the Planning Application and
Final IS/MND. A public hearing will be held by the City Council on Tuesday, February 17, 2015 to
make a decision on the Planning Application and Final IS/MND. Unless substantial modifications
are needed, this Draft IS/MND plus an errata may serve as the final document.
R
EPORT
O
RGANIZATION
This Draft IS/MND is organized into the following sections:
Section 1.0 Introduction. This section summarizes the proposed project and provides information
about the public review and comment process.
Section 2.0: Project Description. This section describes the location and environmental setting of
the proposed project, along with a description of the construction and operational elements of
the project.
Section 3.0: Initial Study Checklist. This section presents an analysis of potential environmental
impacts resulting from implementation of the proposed project.
Section 4.0: Determination. This section identifies the CEQA determination, based on the analysis
contained in this Draft IS/MND, that a Mitigated Negative Declaration is appropriate for the
proposed project.
Section 5.0: Mitigation Measures. This section lists the mitigation measures that are
recommended to be included in the proposed project to reduce impacts to less than
significant.
Section 6.0: References. This section lists the sources of information used to support the
environmental analysis presented in this Draft IS/MND.

i.b: Los Prados Park Turf Conversion Project (PA 14-105)

page.text: P
ROJECT
L
OCATION
Los Prados Park is a 12.6-acre public park operated by the City of San Mateo Department of
Parks and Recreation. It is located in the southeast part of the city south of East Hillsdale
Boulevard/S. Norfolk Street and east of US Highway 101. The park is in a residential area at the
end of a cul-de-sac at 1837 Bahia Street, where there is a signed main entrance and off-street
parking (16 spaces). Local access is also available from Casa de Campo, off La Selva Street,
where there is a second off-street parking lot (36 spaces) adjoining multi-family residential
housing (Figures 1 and 2). A pedestrian pathway from Los Prados Street through single-family
residential development on the east also provides access. There are an additional 11 on-street
parking spaces in which the curb line abuts the park.
P
ROJECT
S
ITE
C
ONDITIONS
The main area of the park is oriented north–south and consists of approximately 5.5 acres of
natural turf field area with baseball diamonds at each end that can accommodate a variety of
uses at the same time, as described below. There are two sections of turf, usually referred to as
the Athletic Field and the Old Section. The Athletic Field is approximately 4.5 acres, and the Old
Section is approximately 1 acre. Other amenities adjoining the Athletic Field include a fenced-in
dog park and several informal picnic areas throughout the park. The main field area serves
multiple sports uses, including baseball, softball, soccer, lacrosse, rugby, and field hockey.
Figure 3 shows the general layout of the Athletic Field.

text.b: Los Prados Park Athletic Field, looking northeast

page.text: There is a paved pathway around the perimeter of the Athletic Field area. A few mature
redwood trees line the southeast corner of the site and slightly smaller redwood trees are
scattered along the west side. Ironbark (eucalyptus), black pine, and cedar trees border the
Los Prados Park also has a tennis court, a basketball court, a children’s playground, and restroom facilities at the north
end on the north side of the Bahia Street cul-de-sac. That portion of the park would not be affected by the proposed
project.

i.b: Los Prados Park Turf Conversion Project (PA 14-105)

page.text: north and northwest sides. Areas that do not contain turf or park amenities are landscaped with
low shrubs with a cover of mulch or soil. There is no field lighting, and none is planned or
proposed.
The Los Prados Athletic Field can generally accommodate one of the following concurrent uses:
one baseball/softball diamond, two baseball/softball diamonds, one soccer field, two soccer
fields, and one baseball/softball diamond plus one soccer field.
From approximately February 1 through late June, only the diamonds are open, and the middle
of the field remains closed to soccer/football/rugby. Field maintenance occurs during this
period, and depending on the need, the middle field is sometimes fenced off. Youth and adult
practice and games occur seven days a week. The field is booked from 3:30 PM or 4:00 PM to
dusk on weekdays and from 8:00 AM to dusk on weekends. In July, weekdays are typically
booked, but weekend use is slightly less. Camps and special events also occur in the summer.
Fall soccer practices and games take place August through November on weekday afternoons.
Weekends are generally booked all day.
The entire Athletic Field is typically closed approximately December 1 through January 31 as a
rest period, and very little maintenance happens during this time.
S
URROUNDING
L
AND
U
SES
Land uses immediately surrounding the park are multi-family housing on the west and north and
single-family residences on the east and south. An approximately 16-foot-high chain-link fence
covered with wood slats and/or vegetation is on the east side of the path adjoining the turf
area. There is also fencing along the south side by the softball diamond.
P
ROJECT
B
ACKGROUND
The City has determined that its park system has a shortage of athletic fields, particularly for
accommodating youth sports programs. Intensive use of existing fields has resulted in greater
need for maintaining play surfaces. In addition, rain can take grass fields out of play for
substantial periods. If grass fields are used before they are sufficiently dry, they can be severely
damaged, which affects playability and results in extensive, regular repairs.
In 2012, the City initiated a project to identify fields that would be most appropriate to convert to
synthetic turf and to establish priority for those fields for turf conversion. The current Capital
Improvement Program (CIP) budget provides sufficient funding to convert at least one field.
Community input was an important element of the planning process. A Community Advisory
Committee (CAC) was established to represent field users, neighborhood interests, and the
general community. The CAC established criteria for assessing each of ten fields for
appropriateness of converting to synthetic turf, reviewed the results of an assessment prepared
by the City’s landscape architect consultant (Callander Associates), and considered public
comments received on the proposal. The City also conducted extensive public outreach.
Project Vicinity

i.b: Los Prados Park Turf Conversion Project (PA 14-105)

page.text: Through City staff planning efforts, consultant recommendations, and CAC input, Los Prados
Park was proposed as the first park for synthetic turf conversion. In July 2013, the City Park and
Recreation Commission voted to support the recommendation for Los Prados Park (San Mateo
2013). In August 2013, the City Council reviewed and informally endorsed the recommendation
during a study session.
P
ROJECT
C
HARACTERISTICS
The proposed project would replace 4.2 acres of grass in the main field area with synthetic turf,
leaving approximately 1 acre of natural turf in the Old Section. The conversion of the natural turf
field to synthetic turf would consist of the following activities:
Removing 10 inches of organic materials and sand drain layer and irrigation lines
from the existing turf area (approximately 6,700 cubic yards of material), which would
be hauled off-site.
Removing one eucalyptus tree, one pine tree, two redwood trees, and one deodar
cedar tree; planting four new trident maple trees and five new redwood trees; and
relocating four redwood trees. If it is not economically feasible to relocate the
redwood trees, new replacement tree(s) would be planted in an area within the park
but not on the Athletic Field.
Importing and placing 9 inches of base rock (approximately 5,500 cubic yards)
above a new geo-stabilizing fabric and the existing perforated drain lines.
Installing perimeter irrigation for trees and landscaping adjoining the Athletic Field.
Installing synthetic turf fiber carpet with sand and crumb-rubber infill over the drain
rock and geo-stabilizing fabric.
Construction activities in other areas of the field would include:
Converting natural turf to mulch and ground cover in the areas of the dripline of
remaining trees.
Installing fencing, landscape bollards, and pathway bollards to control vehicular
access.
Performing pathway repairs and placing an asphalt overlay on the pathways at the
perimeter of the Athletic Field.
Modifying parking lot curbs and layout to meet Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA)
accessible code requirements.
Figure 4 illustrates the project components.
“Fibers” are the material that gives synthetic turf a grass-like look. “Infill” refers to the combination of sand and crumb
rubber used as fill within the synthetic turf fiber material to provide cushioning and traction. Crumb rubber is made up of
ground-up recycled tires. Contract specifications require the use smooth, rounded granules that are produced through
cryogenic freezing.

i.b: Los Prados Park Turf Conversion Project (PA 14-105)

page.text: F
UTURE
O
PERATIONS
The Athletic Field turf conversion would not expand park operations or increase the number of
parking spaces. Park hours would remain identical to current operating hours. No nighttime
lighting would be installed.
The Athletic Field would no longer be closed December through January and would be
available for use. In addition, the middle portion of the field would no longer be closed February
through June, though unless the baseball/softball uses give way to soccer or other field sport
uses, there is unlikely to be a substantial increase in use during this period. After installation of
synthetic turf, maintenance would not typically impede use except in unusual circumstances
(e.g., repair of vandalism).
Based on a review of existing practice and game day use and attendance, it is anticipated that
up to approximately 44 days per year of additional use may be possible by eliminating rain/wet
condition closures. Additional demand may arise on Sundays and for a second soccer field two
weekdays per week in the fall.
The Old Section would remain natural turf, and it is anticipated that there would be no change
to current usage of the Old Section following synthetic turf installation on the Athletic Field.
C
ONSTRUCTION
S
CHEDULE
The turf replacement project is expected to begin in early March 2015 and would be completed
in July 2015 to ensure the field is ready for use by August 1, 2015. Construction would take place
Monday through Friday between the hours of 7:00 AM and 7:00 PM, Saturdays between the
hours of 9:00 AM and 5:00 PM, and Sundays between the hours of 12:00 noon and 4:00 PM, in
accordance with the San Mateo Municipal Code.
Approximately 670 haul truck trips would be used to remove debris, with 550 haul truck trips used
to import materials over the approximately 3.5-month construction schedule Most of the haul
truck trips would be within the first 1–2 weeks of construction, and the two haul periods will be
separated by other work: 1–1.5 weeks for export; 2–4 weeks for other on site work; 1.5–2 weeks
for import. The City’s contractor will be responsible for ensuring haul truck traffic occurs in such a
manner so as to cause as little inconvenience to abutting property owners and motorists as
possible. Truck arrivals and departures would be prohibited from 7:30 to 8:30 AM and from 4:00 to
5:30 PM. A temporary construction staging area would be established adjacent to the existing
parking lot along Casa de Campo, which would be restored to preconstruction conditions once
the project is complete.
In addition, the City’s construction contractor will implement measures in accordance with Bay
Area Air Quality Management District (BAAQMD) regulations to ensure construction dust
emissions are minimized and haul trucks traveling to and from the site are covered. The
regulations are listed in subsection 3.3, Air Quality. The City’s construction contractor will also be
required to implement best management practices and a stormwater pollution prevention plan
(which has already been prepared) to minimize pollutants in runoff from the project site, in
accordance with state requirements (see below) and the City’s Stormwater Management and
Discharge Rules and Regulations (see subsection 3.9, Hydrology and Water Quality).
Source: Beals Alliance

i.b: Los Prados Park Turf Conversion Project (PA 14-105)

page.text: O
PTIONAL
B
ASEBALL
/S
OFTBALL
D
IAMOND
I
NFIELD
T
URF
C
ONVERSION
If funding is available, the City may also replace the baseball/softball diamond infields with
synthetic turf as part of this project. This could include conversion of the southern baseball infield
fines into a slit film synthetic turf infield complete with drainage system modifications, demolition
of existing dugouts, new chain-link fence dugouts, and new asphalt.
At the northern infield, the
infield fines would be replaced with a slit film synthetic turf infield complete with drainage system
modifications. The environmental analyses in this Draft IS/MND cover this optional task.
Required permits and approvals to implement the turf conversion project include this IS/MND, a
Site Development Permit Planning Application, and a Site Development Permit. The City’s
contractor would be required to submit a Notice of Intent (NOI) to the San Francisco Bay
Regional Water Quality Control Board to obtain coverage under the State of California General
Permit for Storm Water Discharges Associated with Construction and Land Disturbance Activities
(State Water Resources Control Board Order No. 2009-0009-DWQ, as amended by 2010-0014-
DWQ).
The following City of San Mateo standard conditions would apply and are assumed part of the
project design for the analysis in this document. Because this project would be constructed by
the City, the conditions have been modified accordingly.
Tree Protection. The City shall protect all major vegetation designated to remain from damage
during construction. Tree protection shall comply with all provisions of the Heritage Tree
Ordinance, approved arborist’s report, and any requirements imposed by the City. The following
tree protection measures shall be shown on drawings:
a) Protective fencing shall be located at the dripline of existing major vegetation to remain.
This protective fencing shall be constructed of solid wood, chain link, or other solid
materials subject to the approval of the Zoning Administrator.
b) All recommendations for tree preservation contained in the approved arborist’s report
and/or additional requirements imposed by the City.
In addition, the following requirements shall be complied with at all times during construction:
c) Oil, gas, chemicals, or construction materials shall not be stored within the dripline of
trees that are designated to be preserved.
d) Signs, wires, or other types of obstructions shall not be attached to trees.
e) Trenching under the dripline of trees is to be avoided. If trenching is necessary, trenches
are to be hand-dug and major roots retained.
“Slit film” refers a type of synthetic turf fiber that has openings in the turf “blade” (as compared to turf blade without
openings). It provides a fiber tough enough to withstand constant wear, such as in a baseball infield. The infill material
would be sand and crumb rubber.

i.b: Los Prados Park Turf Conversion Project (PA 14-105)

page.text: All tree protection measures shall be constructed prior to issuance of a Site Development Permit
for grading.
Permit for Removal of Major Vegetation. A Site Development Permit shall be obtained from the
Planning Division for removal of major vegetation (trees 6 inches in diameter or larger) prior to
the issuance of a grading permit. Fees for tree removal shall be based on the number of trees to
be removed in accordance with City regulations.
Cultural or Archaeological Finds. In the event of the discovery of archaeological resources or
skeletal remains, the City’s contractor shall be responsible for halting construction activities,
notifying the Chief of Planning, and retaining a qualified archaeologist. The archaeologist will be
required to evaluate the uniqueness of the find and to contact local Native American and
historical organizations, and shall recommend a further course of action.
Paleontological Resources. Should any potentially unique paleontological resources (fossils) be
encountered during development activities, work shall be halted immediately within 50 feet of
the discovery. The City of San Mateo Planning Division shall be immediately notified, and the City
shall be responsible for retaining the services of a qualified paleontologist to determine the
significance of the discovery. The paleontologist shall evaluate the uniqueness of the find and
prepare a written report documenting the find and recommending further courses of action.
Based on the significance of the discovery, the actions may include avoidance, preservation in
place, excavation, documentation, recovery, or other appropriate measures as determined by
the paleontologist.
Landscape Water Efficiency. In conformance with California Code of Regulations Title 23,
Division 2, Chapter 2.7 (Model Water Efficiency Landscape Ordinance), the City shall ensure a
Certificate of Completion consistent with California Code of Regulations Title 23, Division 2,
Chapter 2.7.
Stormwater Pollution Prevention Permit. The City shall conduct work in accordance with a
Stormwater Pollution Prevention (STOPPP) Construction permit. In addition, the City shall file a
Notice of Intent (NOI) with the State Water Resources Control Board to obtain coverage under
the State General Construction Activity National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES)
Permit. Proof of permit must be provided to the Public Works Department prior to issuance of the
STOPPP Construction permit. Permits shall be in place prior to issuance of a grading permit.

I
NTRODUCTION
1) A brief explanation is provided for all checklist questions. All answers take account of the
whole action involved, including off-site as well as on-site, cumulative as well as project-level,
indirect as well as direct, and construction as well as operational impacts.
2) The checklist answers indicate whether the impact is potentially significant, less than
significant with mitigation, or less than significant. “Potentially Significant Impact” is
appropriate if there is substantial evidence that an effect may be significant. If there are one
or more “Potentially Significant Impact” entries when the determination is made, an EIR is
required.
3) “Negative Declaration: Less Than Significant With Mitigation Incorporated” applies where the
incorporation of mitigation measures has reduced an effect from “Potentially Significant
Impact” to a “Less Than Significant Impact.” The mitigation measures and brief explanation
how they reduce the effect to a less than significant level are described.
4) Supporting Information Sources: Printed reference material and other sources used or
individuals contacted are identified in the analysis.
I
NITIAL
S
TUDY
C
HECKLIST
The analysis uses the CEQA Guidelines Appendix G Environmental Checklist Form.

i.b: Los Prados Park Turf Conversion Project (PA 14-105)

page.text: 3.1 AESTHETICS. Would the project:
a) Have a substantial adverse effect on a scenic
vista?
b)
Substantially damage scenic resources,
including, but not limited to, trees, rock
outcroppings, and historic buildings within a
state scenic highway?
c) Substantially degrade the existing visual
character or quality of the site and its
surroundings?
d) Create a new source of substantial light or glare
that would adversely affect day or nighttime
views in the area?
E
XISTING
C
ONDITIONS
Los Prados Park is located in an existing urban area of the city that consists of single-family and
multi-family residential uses. The current visual character of the project site consists of active park
features including a large turf field with baseball/softball backstops along the perimeter as well
as a perimeter trail and trees. Other visual features include two parking areas, a dog park, and
other park features.
A
NALYSIS
a, b.
Los Prados Park is not located along a designated scenic highway, nor does it contain
any designated scenic vistas. No impact would occur.
c.
The proposed project would alter the visual character of Los Prados Park during
construction as a result of removal of the existing natural turf and perimeter trees and the
staging of construction equipment adjacent to the existing parking lot along Casa de
Campo, which would be restored to preconstruction conditions following completion of
the project. However, these changes to the visual conditions of the park would be
temporary (3.5 months). Completion of the project would result in the restoration of the
park to visual conditions similar to existing conditions and would not result in a substantial
alteration of the visual character of the site as an active recreation park. Thus, this
impact would be less than significant.
d.
The project would not add new lighting fixtures to the park site. No impact would occur.
Impacts would be the same as described above. There would be no impact.

i.b: Los Prados Park Turf Conversion Project (PA 14-105)

page.text: 3.2 AGRICULTURE AND FORESTRY RESOURCES. In determining whether impacts to agricultural
resources are significant environmental effects, lead agencies may refer to the California Agricultural
Land Evaluation and Site Assessment Model (1997) prepared by the California Department of
Conservation as an optional model to use in assessing impacts on agriculture and farmland. In
determining whether impacts to forest resources, including timberland, are significant environmental
effects, lead agencies may refer to information compiled by the California Department of Forestry
and Fire Protection regarding the state’s inventory of forestland, including the Forest and Range
Assessment Project and the Forest Legacy Assessment project; and forest carbon measurement
methodology provided in Forest Protocols adopted by the California Air Resources Board. Would the
project:
a) Convert Prime Farmland, Unique Farmland, or
Farmland of Statewide Importance (Farmland),
as shown on the maps prepared pursuant to the
Farmland Mapping and Monitoring Program of
the California Resources Agency, to
nonagricultural use?
b) Conflict with existing zoning for agricultural
use, or a Williamson Act contract?
c) Conflict with existing zoning for, or cause
rezoning of, forestland (as defined in Public
Resources Code Section 12220(g)), timberland
(as defined by Public Resources Code Section
4526), or timberland zoned Timberland
Production (as defined by Government Code
Section 51104(g))?
d) Result in the loss of forestland or conversion of
forestland to non-forest use?
e) Involve other changes in the existing
environment which, due to their location or
nature, could result in conversion of Farmland,
to nonagricultural use or conversion of
forestland to non-forest use?
E
XISTING
C
ONDITIONS
The project site is located within an urban area of the City. There is no farmland or agricultural
operations in the project area.
A
NALYSIS
a–e.
The project site is a public park surrounded by residential development. There are no
agriculture or forestry operations. There would be no impact.

i.b: Los Prados Park Turf Conversion Project (PA 14-105)

page.text: Impacts would be the same as described above. There would be no impact.

i.b: Los Prados Park Turf Conversion Project (PA 14-105)

page.text: QUALITY. Where available, the significance criteria established by the applicable air quality
management or air pollution control district may be relied upon to make the following
determinations. Would the project:
a) Conflict with or obstruct implementation of the
applicable air quality plan?
b) Violate any air quality standard or contribute
substantially to an existing or projected air
quality violation?
c) Result in a cumulatively considerable net
increase of any criteria pollutant for which the
project region is in nonattainment under an
applicable federal or state ambient air quality
standard (including releasing emissions that
exceed quantitative thresholds for ozone
precursors)?
d) Expose sensitive receptors to substantial
pollutant concentrations?
e) Create objectionable odors affecting a substantial
number of people?
E
XISTING
C
ONDITIONS
The project site is located within the San Francisco Bay Area Air Basin (SFBAAB). The SFBAAB
comprises a single district, the Bay Area Air Quality Management District (BAAQMD), which
encompasses Napa, Marin, San Francisco, Contra Costa, Alameda, San Mateo, and Santa
Clara counties, the southern portion of Sonoma County, and the western portion of Solano
County. Within the SFBAAB are eleven major climatological subregions. San Mateo is located in
the Peninsula region.
The Peninsula region extends from northwest of San Jose to the Golden Gate Bridge. The Santa
Cruz Mountains run up the center of the Peninsula, with elevations exceeding 2,000 feet at the
southern end and decreasing to 500 feet in South San Francisco. Coastal towns experience a
high incidence of cool, foggy weather in the summer. Cities in the southeastern Peninsula region
experience warmer temperatures and fewer foggy days because the marine layer is blocked by
the ridgeline to the west. The blocking effect of the Santa Cruz Mountains results in variations in
summertime maximum temperatures in different parts of the Peninsula region. For example, in
coastal areas of San Mateo County the mean maximum summer temperatures are in the mid-
60s (Fahrenheit), while in Redwood City the mean maximum summer temperatures are in the
low 80s. Mean minimum temperatures during the winter months are in the high 30s to low 40s on
the eastern side of the Peninsula and in the low 40s on the coast.
Two important gaps in the Santa Cruz Mountains occur on the Peninsula. The larger of the two is
the San Bruno Gap, extending from Fort Funston on the ocean to San Francisco International
Airport. The other gap is the Crystal Springs Gap, between Half Moon Bay and San Carlos. As the

i.b: Los Prados Park Turf Conversion Project (PA 14-105)

page.text: sea breeze strengthens on summer afternoons, the Crystal Springs Gap permits maritime air to
pass across the mountains, and its cooling effect is commonly seen from the City of San Mateo
to Redwood City.
Annual average wind speeds range from 5 to 10 miles per hour throughout the Peninsula, with
higher wind speeds usually found along the coast. Wind speeds on the eastern side of the
Peninsula region are often high in certain areas, such as near the San Bruno Gap and the Crystal
Springs Gap. The prevailing winds along the Peninsula’s coast are from the west, although
individual sites can show significant differences. For example, Fort Funston in western San
Francisco shows a southwest wind pattern, while Pillar Point in San Mateo County shows a
northwest wind pattern. On the east side of the mountains, winds are generally from the west,
although wind patterns in this area are often influenced greatly by local topographic features.
Air pollution potential is highest along the southeastern portion of the Peninsula region (BAAQMD
2011a). This is the area most protected from the high winds and fog of the marine layer. Pollutant
transport from upwind sites is common. In the southeastern portion of the Peninsula region, air
pollutant emissions are relatively high due to motor vehicle traffic and stationary sources
(BAAQMD 2011a).
Both the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and the California Air Resources Board
(CARB) have established ambient air quality standards for common pollutants. These ambient air
quality standards are levels of contaminants representing safe levels that avoid specific adverse
health effects associated with each pollutant. The ambient air quality standards cover what are
called “criteria” pollutants because the health and other effects of each pollutant are
described in criteria documents. The six criteria air pollutants are ozone (O
), carbon monoxide
(CO), nitrogen dioxide (NO
), sulfur dioxide (SO
), coarse particulate matter (PM
), and fine
particulate matter (PM
). Areas that meet ambient air quality standards are classified as
attainment areas, while areas that do not meet these standards are classified as nonattainment
areas. The SFBAAB is currently designated as nonattainment for the state and federal ambient
air quality standards for ground-level O
and PM
as well as for the state standards for PM
A
NALYSIS
a.
As previously stated, the project site is located within the SFBAAB, which comprises a
single air district, the Bay Area Air Quality Management District. The project site is located
in the Peninsula region of the air basin. The BAAQMD prepares plans to attain ambient air
quality standards in the air basin. The BAAQMD also prepares ozone attainment plans for
the national ozone standard and clean air plans for the California standard, both in
coordination with the Metropolitan Transportation Commission (MTC) and the Association
of Bay Area Governments (ABAG).
The BAAQMD prepared the Bay Area 2010 Clean Air Plan to address the air basin’s
nonattainment status with the national 1-hour ozone standard and the California
ambient air quality standards (CAAQS).
The purpose of the Clean Air Plan is to:
1. Update the Bay Area 2005 Ozone Strategy in accordance with the requirements of
the California Clean Air Act to implement all feasible measures to reduce ozone;
The Bay Area Air Quality Management District is preparing an update to the Bay Area Clean Air Plan. In
February 2014, BAAQMD staff held a workshop to initiate the process of updating the Clean Air Plan.

i.b: Los Prados Park Turf Conversion Project (PA 14-105)

page.text: 2. Consider the impacts of ozone control measures on particulate matter (PM), air
toxics, and greenhouse gases in a single, integrated plan;
3. Review progress in improving air quality in recent years; and
4. Establish emission control measures to be adopted or implemented in the 2009–2012
time frame.
The emissions inventories contained in the ozone attainment plan and the Clean Air Plan
are based on projected population growth and vehicle miles traveled (VMT) for the
region. These inventories are largely based on the predicted growth identified in regional
and community general plans, including associated development projects. Projects that
result in an increase in population or employment growth beyond that identified in
regional or community plans could result in increases in VMT and subsequently increase
mobile source emissions, which would not have been accounted for in the BAAQMD’s air
quality plans, making the projects inconsistent with the plans.
The proposed project is consistent with the land use designation of the City’s General
Plan; therefore, the proposed project would not result in an increase in population or
employment growth, and thus VMT, beyond that anticipated in the ozone attainment
plan and the Clean Air Plan. Therefore, the proposed project would not conflict with or
obstruct implementation of the ozone attainment plan or the Clean Air Plan.
A project is also determined to be consistent with these air quality plans if the project
includes applicable control measures in the plans and does not disrupt or hinder
implementation of any control measures. As discussed in more detail under Item b,
below, the proposed project would not result in construction-generated or operational-
related criteria air pollutants and/or precursor emissions that would exceed the BAAQMD
thresholds of significance. Furthermore, although not required for consistency with these
plans, adherence to mitigation measures AQ-1 and AQ-2 would further reduce project
emissions and ensure project consistency with the air quality plans.
The proposed project would support the goals of the ozone attainment plan and the
Clean Air Plan, would include feasible control measures, would not disrupt or hinder
implementation of any control measures, and would not result in vehicle trips greater
than the projected population increase for the project site. Therefore, the project would
be considered consistent with BAAQMD air quality plans, resulting in a less than
significant impact.
b.

construction- and/or operational-related criteria air pollutant and precursor impacts, the
proposed project must emit no more than 54 pounds per day (lbs/day) of the O
precursors (reactive organic gases (ROG) and/or nitrogen oxides (NOx)), no more than

material removal phase would exceed the BAAQMD’s thresholds of significance for NOx
emissions, which would be considered a potentially significant impact and require
mitigation to reduce emissions to a level below the threshold. NOx emissions are primarily
associated with use of diesel-powered construction equipment (e.g., graders,
excavators, rubber-tired dozers, tractors, loaders, backhoes). The Clean Air Act of 1990
directed the EPA to study, and regulate if warranted, the contribution of off-road internal
combustion engines to urban air pollution. The first federal standards (Tier 1) for new off-
road diesel engines were adopted in 1994 for engines over 50 horsepower and were
phased in from 1996 to 2000. In 1996, a Statement of Principles pertaining to off-road
diesel engines was signed between the EPA, CARB, and engine makers (including
Caterpillar, Cummins, Deere, Detroit Diesel, Deutz, Isuzu, Komatsu, Kubota, Mitsubishi,

i.b: Los Prados Park Turf Conversion Project (PA 14-105)

page.text: Navistar, New Holland, Wis-Con, and Yanmar). On August 27, 1998, the EPA signed the
final rule reflecting the provisions of the Statement of Principles. The 1998 regulation
introduced Tier 1 standards for equipment under 50 horsepower and increasingly more
stringent Tier 2 and Tier 3 standards for all equipment with phase-in schedules from 2000
to 2008. As a result, all off-road, diesel-fueled construction equipment manufactured in
2006 or later has been manufactured to Tier 3 standards. On May 11, 2004, the EPA
signed the final rule introducing Tier 4 emission standards, which are currently phased-in
over the period of 2008–2015. The Tier 4 standards require that emissions of PM and NOx
be further reduced by about 90 percent. All off-road, diesel-fueled construction
equipment manufactured in 2015 or later will be manufactured to Tier 4 standards.
With implementation of mitigation measure AQ-1, temporary NOx emissions impacts
generated during project construction would be reduced to a less than significant level
by requiring the use of Tier 4 construction equipment during the organic material removal
phase, as shown in Table AQ-2.

The SFBAAB is currently designated as nonattainment for the state and federal ambient
air quality standards for ground-level O
and PM
as well as for the state standards for
PM
(CARB 2013). The air basin’s nonattainment status is attributed to the region’s
development history. Past, present, and future development projects contribute to the
region’s adverse air quality impacts on a cumulative basis. By its very nature, air pollution
is largely a cumulative impact. According to the BAAQMD, no single project is sufficient
in size, by itself, to result in nonattainment of ambient air quality standards. Instead, a
project’s individual emissions contribute to existing cumulatively significant adverse air
quality impacts. In developing thresholds of significance for air pollutants, the BAAQMD
considered the emission levels for which a project’s individual emissions would be
cumulatively considerable. According to the BAAQMD, if a project exceeds its identified
significance thresholds, the project would be cumulatively considerable. As
demonstrated under Impact b, the proposed project would not exceed BAAQMD
thresholds for air pollutant emissions during construction or operations (see Tables AQ-1
and AQ-2) with the implementation of mitigation measure AQ-1. Therefore, since the
project does not exceed BAAQMD significance thresholds, it would result in less than
significant cumulative impacts.
d.
Sensitive receptors are generally defined as uses that house or attract groups of children,
the elderly, people with illnesses, and others who are especially sensitive to the effects of
air pollutants. Schools, hospitals, residential areas, and convalescent facilities are
examples of sensitive receptors. The project site is considered a sensitive receptor
(following construction of recreational uses) and is adjacent to other residential areas.
Short-Term Construction Diesel Particulate Matter Emissions
Construction activities would involve the use of a variety of gasoline- or diesel-powered
equipment that emits exhaust fumes (diesel exhaust particulate matter) and generates
dust during soil disturbance (fugitive dust particulate matter). These temporary air quality
impacts could negatively affect sensitive receptors in the project area. However, the
duration of exposure would be short and exhaust from construction equipment dissipates
rapidly. Furthermore, as identified under Impact b, project construction would not
exceed BAAQMD thresholds for particulate matter. Additionally, mitigation measure
AQ-1 reduces the amount of construction-generated diesel exhaust particulate matter
and other pollutants by requiring the most efficient equipment. For instance, the Tier 4
standards, required by mitigation measure AQ-1, reduce emissions of particulate matter
and NOx by more than 50 percent. Nonetheless, sensitive receptors could still be
exposed to nuisance levels of fugitive dust. Therefore, mitigation measure AQ-2, which
includes standard BAAQMD dust control measures, is required. With implementation of
mitigation measures AQ-1 and AQ-2, sensitive receptors in the project vicinity would not
be exposed to substantial diesel exhaust particulate matter or fugitive dust particulate

i.b: Los Prados Park Turf Conversion Project (PA 14-105)

page.text: matter emissions and temporary impacts from construction-generated air toxics would
be reduced to a less than significant level.
Localized Carbon Monoxide
Localized carbon monoxide concentrations near roadway intersections are a function of
traffic volume, speed, and delay. Transport of CO is extremely limited because carbon
monoxide disperses rapidly with distance from the source.
Based on BAAQMD guidance, projects meeting all of the following screening criteria
would be considered to have a less than significant impact to localized carbon
monoxide concentrations:
The project is consistent with an applicable congestion management program
established by the county congestion management agency for designated
roads or highways, regional transportation plans, and local congestion
management agency plans.
The project traffic would not increase traffic volumes at affected intersections to
more than 44,000 vehicles per hour.
The project traffic would not increase traffic volumes at affected intersections to
more than 24,000 vehicles per hour where vertical and/or horizontal mixing is
substantially limited (e.g., tunnel, parking garage, bridge underpass, natural or
urban street canyon, below-grade roadway).
The project would not increase traffic volumes at any intersection to more than 44,000
vehicles per hour or 24,000 vehicles per hour as determined traffic analysis prepared for
the project. As previously described, the proposed project is not projected to cause any
increase in intensity of use that would result in an increased number of vehicle trips to
and from the project site during any specific time of day or month of the year beyond
the existing typical usage pattern. Therefore, traffic conditions after the project is
completed are expected to be the same as existing traffic conditions. As such, the
proposed project would not exceed the BAAQMD’s significance thresholds for carbon
monoxide.
Toxic Air Contaminants
There are many different types of toxic air contaminants (TACs), with varying degrees of
toxicity. Sources of TACs include commercial operations, such as gasoline stations and
dry cleaners. Mobile sources of air toxics include freeways and major roadways. These
roadways are sources of diesel particulate matter (DPM), which CARB has listed as a
toxic air contaminant. In addition to the thresholds described previously relating to
criteria air pollutants and CO hotspots, the BAAQMD considers projects that would result
in either an excess cancer risk level of more than 10 in one million, a non-cancer (i.e.,
chronic or acute) hazard index greater than 1.0, and/or an incremental increase of
greater than 0.3 µg/m
(micrograms per cubic meter) annual average PM
to be a
significant impact. The proposed project would not be a source of TACs. However, there
is a potential that the project site could be exposed to TAC emissions from stationary
and/or mobile sources. Per BAAQMD guidance, all TAC sources within 1,000 feet of a
proposed sensitive receptor need to be identified and analyzed.

i.b: Los Prados Park Turf Conversion Project (PA 14-105)

page.text: According to the BAAQMD’s (2012a) Stationary Source Screening Analysis Tool, there are
no stationary sources of TACs within 1,000 feet of the project site. The nearest source is
located on 406 Santa Clara Way approximately 1,770 feet to the west (BAAQMD 2012a).
Therefore, stationary-source TAC emissions would not result in a risk to future sensitive
receptors of the proposed project.
In terms of mobile TAC sources, the site is approximately 450 feet east of US Highway 101,
which is within the BAAQMD-recommended buffer area of 1,000 feet. TAC
concentrations associated with US Highway 101 were identified by the BAAQMD’s
(2011b) Highway Source Screening Analysis Tool and were then refined to account for
specific distance between the highway and project sensitive receptors with the
BAAQMD’s (2012b) Distance Adjustment Multiplier Tool. According to this analysis,
sensitive receptors at the project site would be exposed to a cancer risk level of 4.72 in
one million, a non-cancer hazard index of 0.028, and an annual average 0.04 µg/m
PM
. Therefore, the project site is not exposed to levels of TAC emissions considered to
be significant by the BAAQMD.
For the reasons noted, the project site would not be negatively affected by TACs
generated at any stationary sources or on US Highway 101. Impacts to sensitive receptors
are considered to be less than significant.
Mitigation Measures
Prior to the issuance of grading or building permits, the
construction contractor shall ensure that the Bay Area Air Quality
Management District’s (BAAQMD) basic construction mitigation measures
from Table 8-1 of the BAAQMD 2011 CEQA Air Quality Guidelines are noted on
the construction documents. These basic construction mitigation measures
include the following:
1. All exposed surfaces (e.g., parking areas, staging areas, soil piles, graded
areas, and unpaved access roads) shall be watered two times per day.
2. All haul trucks transporting soil, sand, or other loose material off-site shall
be covered.
3. All visible mud or dirt track-out onto adjacent public roads shall be
removed using wet power vacuum street sweepers at least once per day.
The use of dry power sweeping is prohibited.
4. All roadways, driveways, and sidewalks to be paved shall be completed
as soon as possible.
5. All construction equipment shall be maintained and properly tuned in
accordance with manufacturers’ specifications. All equipment shall be
checked by a certified mechanic and determined to be running in
proper condition prior to operation.
6. A publicly visible sign shall be posted with the telephone number and
person to contact at the lead agency regarding dust complaints. This
person shall respond and take corrective action within 48 hours. The
BAAQMD’s phone number shall also be visible to ensure compliance with
applicable regulations.

ONDITIONS
The project site consists of approximately 5.5 acres of grass turf play field, two softball/baseball
diamonds, landscaped areas with low shrubs along the edge of the turf in a few locations, and
a variety of native and non-native trees along the perimeter. No riparian habitat or sensitive
natural community is located at the project site. There are no federally protected wetlands,
waters of the United States, or waters of the State on the project site.
The site is approximately 1,000 feet from the nearest natural surface water feature (Marina
Lagoon). Marina Lagoon covers 185 acres and is approximately 4.5 miles long. While the lagoon
primarily serves a flood control purpose, it also has recreational, aesthetic, and wildlife value. The

i.b: Los Prados Park Turf Conversion Project (PA 14-105)

page.text: lagoon includes a small island at the mouth of the former Seal Slough which supports roosting,
nesting, and feeding shorebirds and waterfowl. In 1999, the City’s Public Works Department
developed the Marina Lagoon Management Plan, which recognizes the need to manage the
lagoon in a manner that balances its three primary purposes: flood control, wildlife habitat, and
recreation (San Mateo 2010a).
A
NALYSIS
a.
Numerous laboratory studies have analyzed the potential for synthetic turf to leach
harmful chemicals into the environment. Based on these studies reported in published
literature, stormwater runoff from the synthetic turf would not have an adverse effect on
aquatic or wildlife habitat or species at Marina Lagoon, which drains to San Francisco
Bay. The reports cited in this Draft IS/MND (see Impact b in subsection 3.8, Hazards and
Hazardous Materials, and Impact f in subsection 3.9, Hydrology and Water Quality)
provide multiple lines of evidence that synthetic turf and infill materials do not leach or
introduce toxins or other chemical constituents into the aquatic environmental that
exceed acceptable levels or would trigger an impact under CEQA. Moreover, any
measurable residual levels of contaminants identified in the studies would be significantly
diluted compared to controlled laboratory samples as they percolate through 12 inches
of drain rock into the perforated drain lines connected to the City’s storm drain system
and mix with drainage waters from the entire Seal Slough watershed. For these reasons,
as supported by the findings in subsections 3.8 and 3.9, the project would have no
impact on special-status species or habitats, including the aquatic species of Marina
Lagoon and San Francisco Bay.
b.
The extent of project improvements are limited Los Prados Park (a developed active park
facility) within a developed urban area of the city. No riparian habitat or other sensitive
natural community exists in the project area. Thus, no impact to riparian habitat or other
sensitive natural community would occur.
c.
The project site is an existing turf sports/athletic field. It is approximately 1,000 feet from
the nearest natural surface water feature (Marina Lagoon). There are no federally
protected wetlands, waters of the United States, or waters of the State on the project
site. There would be no impact.
d.
The project site is in a densely urbanized residential area, and there are no natural or
artificial surface water features on the site. It does not provide a migratory fish or wildlife
corridor function. Canada geese currently use the natural turf for grazing. The conversion
to synthetic turf would remove approximately 4 acres of natural turf, which would likely
reduce the number of Canada geese at the park. However, there are numerous other
nearby locations suitable for Canada geese to graze, and the removal of natural turf
would not impede goose migration or nursery sites. Impacts would be less than
significant.
e.
The proposed project could result in the removal of up to one black pine (Pinus
thunbergii), one red ironbark (Eucalyptus sideroxylon), one deodar cedar (Cedrus
deodara), and six redwood trees (Sequioa sempervirens). The red ironbark and
redwoods meet the definition of a heritage tree, according to the City’s Heritage Tree
Ordinance (Municipal Code Chapter 13.52). A certified arborist determined that the
redwood trees planned for removal are young and vigorous, with dense, health foliage.
Transplanting the redwoods could be successful, but the cost could be substantial
because it would require a large excavation area and a crane. If it is not economically

i.b: Los Prados Park Turf Conversion Project (PA 14-105)

page.text: feasible to relocate the redwood trees, new redwood trees would be planted in the park
outside the Athletic Field. The arborist was of the opinion that removing and replacing
the trees is the best option in terms of cost and maintenance. The City’s Heritage Tree
Ordinance provides for removal of a heritage tree. Tree removal and replacement must
be performed under the direction of a certified arborist. Replacement of the trees would
be consistent with General Plan Policy C/OS 6.2 (heritage tree replacement planting).
Municipal Code Section 13.52.070 also requires that notification of removal of a heritage
tree be provided to abutting property owners.
Some trees along the perimeter of the Athletic Field may require pruning. The City’s
standard conditions identify specific tree protection measures that must be implemented
by the construction contractor. This would include tree protection measures as well as
the Heritage Tree Ordinance requirements for tree protection. These requirements would
be noted in contract specifications.
Therefore, the proposed project would not be in conflict with applicable policies and
ordinances regarding heritage trees. Impacts would be less than significant.
f.
No adopted habitat conservation plan, natural community conservation plan, or other
approved local, regional, or state habitat conservation plan is applicable to the project
site. There would be no impact.
Replacement of the infields with synthetic turf would not result in any new or substantial increase
in biological resources impacts other than those described above.

ONDITIONS
The city has been mapped for archaeological sensitivity. The “high sensitivity” zone includes
recorded archaeological sites and the immediate area that are favorable sites, such as San
Mateo Creek. The “medium sensitivity” zone includes areas surrounding the high sensitivity areas
and other locales where, while no sites are recorded, the settings are similar to those where
recorded sites do occur. The majority of the city is in a “low sensitivity” zone wherein
archaeological resources are not generally expected but may occur (San Mateo 2010a).
The project site is a City-operated park surrounded by urban development built on fill. There are
no structures on the project site. The existing natural turf is on sand with a drainage layer.
A
NALYSIS
a.
There are no structures or features on the project site other than the sports field and park
amenities, which are modern features. No impact would occur.
b, c.
The proposed project would result in the removal of approximately 12 inches of turf and
underlying sand and drain layer in an area underlain by non-native fill materials. This
would not be expected to encounter buried archaeological materials or fossils. In the
unlikely event such resources are discovered, City standard conditions pertaining to
archaeological finds and paleontological resources would ensure any discovery is
managed properly. Impacts would be less than significant.
d.
There are no cemeteries or known human burials at the site. In the unlikely event remains
are discovered, the City would be responsible for compliance with California Health and
Safety Code Section 7050.5 and CEQA Guidelines Section 15064.5. Impacts would be less
than significant.

i.b: Los Prados Park Turf Conversion Project (PA 14-105)

page.text: Replacement of the infields with synthetic turf would not result in any new or substantial increase
in cultural resources impacts other than those described above. There would be no impact on
historical resources and less than significant impacts for other resources.

i.b: Los Prados Park Turf Conversion Project (PA 14-105)

page.text: GEOLOGY AND SOILS. Would the project:
a) Expose people or structures to potential
substantial adverse effects, including the risk of
loss, injury, or death, involving:
i) Rupture of a known earthquake fault, as
delineated on the most recent Alquist-Priolo
Earthquake Fault Zoning Map issued by the
State Geologist for the area or based on
other substantial evidence of a known fault?
Refer to Division of Mines and Geology
Special Publication 42.
ii) Strong seismic ground shaking?
iii) Seismic-related ground failure, including
liquefaction?
iv) Landslides?
b) Result in substantial soil erosion or the loss of
topsoil?
c) Be located on a geologic unit or soil that is
unstable, or that would become unstable as a
result of the project, and potentially result in on-
or off-site landslide, lateral spreading,
subsidence, liquefaction, or collapse?
d) Be located on expansive soil, as defined in
Section 1803.5.3 of the 2013 California
Building Code, creating substantial risks to life
or property?
e) Have soils incapable of adequately supporting
the use of septic tanks or alternative wastewater
disposal systems where sewers are not available
for the disposal of wastewater?
E
XISTING
C
ONDITIONS
A geotechnical report was prepared for the proposed project to aid in the design and
construction of the project. The Athletic Field surface is covered with natural grass turf. The
baseball/softball diamonds are covered with dirt cinder. The existing natural turf is underlain by
fine-grained sand overlying dense sandy gravel. Low-plasticity sandy clay fill soil underlies the
gravel. The existing sand and gravel materials are highly permeable (Miller Pacific 2014).

i.b: Los Prados Park Turf Conversion Project (PA 14-105)

page.text: A
NALYSIS
a.i.
There are no active faults on or adjacent to the project site (DOC 2014). There would be
no impact.
a.ii.
The project site could be subject to strong ground shaking from an earthquake on the
San Andreas fault or other regional fault. This is an existing condition. The replacement of
natural turf with synthetic turf would not involve new features or structures or an increase
in population that could be exposed to seismic hazards. Impacts would be less than
significant.
a.iii.
The project site has not been mapped by the State as an area requiring investigation for
liquefaction hazard (DOC 2014). There would be no impact.
a.iv
The project site is flat. There is no landslide hazard, and there would be no impact.
b.
There is no topsoil at the project site, which is covered with natural grass turf and
landscaping. A potential exists for soil erosion during construction when the grass is
removed, exposing the underlying sand layer. The City’s construction contractor would
be required to implement BAAQMD dust control measures (see subsection 3.3, Air
Quality) and construction site stormwater runoff controls (see subsection 3.9, Hydrology
and Water Quality). This would reduce the potential for erosion of sediment and silt from
the site. After the synthetic turf is installed, all exposed soil materials would be covered,
and there would be no potential for erosion. Impacts would be less than significant.
c.
The geotechnical report prepared for the proposed project concluded that the
proposed project design is feasible from a geotechnical perspective without the need
for special or unusual engineering. Implementation of the recommendations in the report
(testing imported fill material for suitability, compacting materials to achieve a firm and
uniform subgrade, and maintaining permeability) would ensure proper stability of the
new turf field (Miller Pacific 2014). Impacts would be less than significant.
d.
The proposed project does not involve the construction of new structures or features that
could subject to expansive soil characteristics. There would be no impact.
e.
The proposed project would not involve the use of septic systems. Restroom facilities at
the park are connected to the City’s sewer system. There would be no impact.
Replacement of the infields with synthetic turf would not result in any new or substantial increase
in geology and soils impacts other than those described above. Impacts would be less than
significant.

i.b: Los Prados Park Turf Conversion Project (PA 14-105)

page.text: GREENHOUSE GAS EMISSIONS. Would the project:
a) Generate greenhouse gas emissions, either
directly or indirectly, that may have a significant
impact on the environment?
b) Conflict with an applicable plan, policy, or
regulation adopted for the purpose of reducing
the emissions of greenhouse gases?
E
XISTING
C
ONDITIONS
Since the early 1990s, scientific consensus holds that the world’s population is releasing
greenhouse gases (GHG) faster than the earth’s natural systems can absorb them. These gases
are released as byproducts of fossil fuel combustion, waste disposal, energy use, land-use
changes, and other human activities. This release of gases, such as carbon dioxide (CO
methane (CH
), and nitrous oxide (N
O), and chlorofluorocarbons, creates a blanket around the
earth that allows light to pass through but traps heat at the surface preventing its escape into
space. While this is a naturally occurring process known as the greenhouse effect, human
activities have accelerated the generation of GHGs beyond natural levels. The overabundance
of GHGs in the atmosphere has led to an unexpected warming of the earth and has the
potential to severely impact the earth’s climate system.
Table GHG-1 provides descriptions of the primary GHGs attributed to global climate change,
including a description of their physical properties, primary sources, and contribution to the
greenhouse effect.
Carbon dioxide (CO
CO
is a colorless, odorless gas and is emitted in a number of ways, both naturally and
through human activities. The largest source of CO
emissions globally is the
combustion of fossil fuels such as coal, oil, and gas in power plants, automobiles,
industrial facilities, and other sources. A number of industrial production processes and
product uses such as mineral production, metal production, and the use of petroleum-
based products can also lead to CO
emissions. The atmospheric lifetime of CO
is
variable because it is so readily exchanged in the atmosphere.
Methane (CH
CH
is a colorless, odorless gas that is not flammable under most circumstances. CH
is
the major component of natural gas, about 87 percent by volume. It is also formed and
released to the atmosphere by biological processes occurring in anaerobic
environments. CH
is emitted from both human-related and natural sources. Human-
related sources include fossil fuel production, animal husbandry (livestock intestinal
fermentation and manure management), biomass burning, and waste management.
These activities release significant quantities of CH
to the atmosphere. Natural sources
of CH
include wetlands, gas hydrates, permafrost, termites, oceans, freshwater bodies,
non-wetland soils, and other sources such as wildfires. Methane‘s atmospheric lifetime
is about 12 years.

i.b: Los Prados Park Turf Conversion Project (PA 14-105)

page.text: Nitrous oxide (N
O)
N
O is a clear, colorless gas with a slightly sweet odor. N
O is produced by natural and
human-related sources. Primary human-related sources are agricultural soil
management, animal manure management, sewage treatment, mobile and stationary
combustion of fossil fuels, adipic acid production, and nitric acid production. N
O is
also produced naturally from a wide variety of biological sources in soil and water,
particularly microbial action in wet tropical forests. The atmospheric lifetime of N
O is
approximately 120 years.

text.i: Sources:
EPA 2011a,
EPA 2011b,
EPA 2010

page.text: Each GHG differs in its ability to absorb heat in the atmosphere based on the lifetime, or
persistence, of the gas molecule in the atmosphere. CH
traps over 21 times more heat per
molecule than CO
, and N
O absorbs 310 times more heat per molecule than CO
. Often,
estimates of GHG emissions are presented in carbon dioxide equivalents (CO
e), which weight
each gas by its GWP. Expressing GHG emissions in carbon dioxide equivalents takes the
contribution of all GHG emissions to the greenhouse effect and converts them to a single unit
equivalent to the effect that would occur if only CO
were being emitted.
The City of San Mateo is currently in the process of preparing a Climate Action Plan (CAP) to
address climate change and reduce the community’s GHG emissions at the local level as well
as build on the City’s current Greenhouse Gas Reduction Program. Once prepared, the CAP will
identify GHG reduction targets that are based on the achievement of 1990 emissions levels as
defined by the Global Warming Solutions Act (AB 32), as well as demonstrate feasible and
actionable measures which provide certainty that the City will achieve the identified reduction
targets. The CAP will serve as a Qualified GHG Reduction Strategy, consistent with CEQA
Guidelines Section 15183.5 and the BAAQMD GHG Plan Level Guidance. As part of the
requirements for a Qualified GHG Reduction Strategy, the CAP will include an inventory and
forecast of San Mateo’s current and future GHG emissions, a target to reduce community-wide
GHG emissions, specific strategies to achieve these reductions, and an implementation and
monitoring program to track progress toward the target and the status of the reduction
strategies. The CAP will also include environmental review consistent with CEQA and a General
Plan Amendment.
A
NALYSIS
a.
GHG emissions contribute, on a cumulative basis, to the significant adverse
environmental impacts of global climate change. No single project could generate
enough GHG emissions to noticeably change the global average temperature. The
combination of GHG emissions from past, present, and future projects contributes
substantially to the phenomenon of global climate change and its associated
environmental impacts and as such is addressed only as a cumulative impact.
GHG emissions associated with the project would occur over the short term from
construction activities, consisting primarily of emissions from equipment exhaust.
Construction. The BAAQMD does not have an adopted threshold of significance for
construction-related GHG emissions. However, the BAAQMD recommends quantification
and disclosure of GHG emissions that would occur during construction, in addition to
making a determination on the significance of these construction-generated GHG
emissions impacts in relation to meeting AB 32 greenhouse gas reduction goals. AB 32 is
the California Global Warming Solutions Act, enacted by the State Legislature in
September 2006. AB 32 requires the reduction of statewide GHG emissions to 1990 levels

i.b: Los Prados Park Turf Conversion Project (PA 14-105)

page.text: by 2020. Construction of the proposed project would result in direct emissions of GHGs
from construction. The approximate quantity of daily GHG emissions generated by
construction equipment utilized to build the proposed project is depicted in Table
As shown in Table GHG-2, the construction of the proposed project would result in a
maximum of 213 metric tons of construction-generated CO
e over an estimated 3.5-
month construction period.
Site Preparation
Organic Material Removal
Facility Demolition
Drainage Rock Import & Distribution
Synthetic Turf Installation

scenario. Refer to Appendix A for model data outputs.
Notes:

removals.
2. Accounts for the removal of fencing, dugouts, wood backstops and benches, pavement, and curbs equaling 30.5 tons.
