parking lot modification/reconfiguration.

page.text: In addition to quantifying construction-generated GHG emissions, the BAAQMD
recommends that all construction projects incorporate best management practices
minimizing GHG emissions. Mitigation measure AQ-1, included in subsection 3.3, Air
Quality, would require the use of the most efficient heavy-duty diesel-powered equipment
during the organic material removal phase of construction. Implementation of this
measure would minimize construction-related emissions, consistent with AB 32 reduction
goals, and would therefore result in a less than significant impact.
Operation. The BAAQMD threshold of significance applicable to the project is whether
the project would exceed 1,100 metric tons per year of CO
e. However, the proposed
project would not include the provision of new permanent sources of GHG emissions;
therefore, by its very nature, it would not generate quantifiable criteria emissions from
project operations. For instance, the project does not propose any buildings and
therefore no permanent source of stationary source emissions. In addition, as described
subsection 3.17, Utilities and Service Systems, while the proposed project would require
water for irrigation, the acres of grass proposed to be replaced with synthetic turf would
eliminate the need for consistent irrigation (some water would still be used to periodically
clean the synthetic turf), and overall water demand would decrease from existing

i.b: Los Prados Park Turf Conversion Project (PA 14-105)

page.text: conditions. Therefore, the proposed project would not result in increased demand for
water supplies and thus would not result in the generation of GHG emissions from
increased water pumping. Also, as determined in the traffic analysis prepared for the
project), the proposed project is not projected to cause any increase in intensity of use
that would result in an increased number of vehicle trips to and from the project site
during any specific time of day or month of the year beyond the existing typical usage
pattern. Traffic conditions after the project is completed are expected to be the same as
the existing traffic conditions. Therefore, there would be no new mobile sources of
emissions.
The proposed project would not result in the long-term generation of GHG emissions and
would not exceed BAAQMD greenhouse gas thresholds of significance. This is a less than
significant impact.
b.
As previously stated, the City of San Mateo is currently in the process of preparing a CAP
to address GHG emissions; however, the plan has yet to be adopted. The City is subject
to compliance with AB 32. As noted earlier, AB 32 is a legal mandate requiring that
statewide GHG emissions be reduced to 1990 levels by 2020. In adopting AB 32, the State
Legislature determined the necessary GHG reductions for California to make in order to
sufficiently offset its contribution to the cumulative climate change problem to reach
1990 levels. AB 32 is the only legally mandated requirement for the reduction of GHG
emissions. As such, compliance with AB 32 is the adopted basis on which a lead agency
can base its significance threshold for evaluating the project’s GHG impacts. As
identified above, the proposed project would not surpass the BAAQMD’s GHG
significance threshold of 1,100 metric tons per year of CO
e, which was developed with
the purpose of complying with the requirements of AB 32. BAAQMD thresholds were
developed based on substantial evidence that such thresholds represent quantitative
levels of GHG emissions, compliance with which means that the environmental impact of
the GHG emissions will normally not be cumulatively considerable under CEQA
(BAAQMD 2011a). Compliance with such thresholds will be part of the solution to the
cumulative GHG emissions problem, rather than hinder the State’s ability to meet its
goals of reduced statewide GHG emissions under AB 32. Therefore, the proposed project
would not conflict with AB 32, and there is no significant impact.
The emissions projections above account for the potential replacement of the baseball/softball
diamond infields with synthetic turf and associated facility demolition, and would therefore not
result in any new or substantial increase in GHG emission impacts beyond those described
above.

i.b: Los Prados Park Turf Conversion Project (PA 14-105)

page.text: HAZARDS AND HAZARDOUS MATERIALS. Would the project:
a) Create a significant hazard to the public or the
environment through the routine transport, use,
or disposal of hazardous materials?
b) Create a significant hazard to the public or the
environment through reasonably foreseeable
upset and accident conditions involving the
release of hazardous materials into the
environment?
c) Emit hazardous emissions or handle hazardous or
acutely hazardous materials, substances, or waste
within one-quarter mile of an existing or
proposed school?
d) Be located on a site which is included on a list of
hazardous materials sites compiled pursuant to
Government Code Section 65962.5 and, as a
result, would it create a significant hazard to the
public or the environment?
e) For a project located within an airport land use
plan area or, where such a plan has not been
adopted, within 2 miles of a public airport or a
public use airport, would the project result in a
safety hazard for people residing or working in
the project area?
f) For a project within the vicinity of a private
airstrip, would the project result in a safety
hazard for people residing or working in the
project area?
g) Impair implementation of, or physically interfere
with, an adopted emergency response plan or
emergency evacuation plan?
h) Expose people or structures to a significant risk of
loss, injury, or death involving wildland fires,
including where wildlands are adjacent to
urbanized areas or where residences are
intermixed with wildlands?
E
XISTING
C
ONDITIONS
Los Prados Park is a public park in an urbanized area surrounded by residential uses. Hazardous
materials use at the Athletic Field and perimeter landscaping is limited to landscape products
such as pesticides and herbicides that are used consistent with state and federal requirements.

i.b: Los Prados Park Turf Conversion Project (PA 14-105)

page.text: A
NALYSIS
a.
Construction of the proposed project would involve the use of heavy equipment
containing fuel and other petroleum products, application of herbicides prior to turf grass
removal at the Athletic Field, paints for parking space restriping, and asphalt. Regulations
at the federal, state, and local levels are intended to minimize potential hazards to the
public and the environment from the improper handling or accidental release of
hazardous materials. The City’s construction contractor would be responsible for ensuring
compliance with applicable regulations during any construction activities involving
hazardous materials use or the generation of hazardous waste. It is anticipated that there
would be a reduction in pesticide and herbicide use because synthetic turf would not
require such products. Therefore, the proposed project would not create a significant
hazard to the public or the environment through the routine transport, use, or disposal of
hazardous materials, and impacts would be less than significant.
b.
The proposed project would result in the removal of natural grass turf and replacement
with synthetic turf. The synthetic turf infill would be composed of crumb rubber, which is
made up of recycled tires. The tire materials contain a variety of chemicals, including
organic compounds and metals. This Initial Study’s analysis of potential hazardous
materials emissions and effects on public health is based on a literature review of
numerous studies conducted on installed synthetic turf systems, identified below. The
studies evaluate the potential for synthetic turf systems to emit or release contaminants
into the environment (air, stormwater runoff, and groundwater). Testing of numerous
synthetic field materials has been conducted by several agencies including, but not
limited to, the EPA, Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection (DEP),
California Office of Environmental Health Hazard Assessment (OEHHA), Norwegian
Institute for Air Research (NILU), Connecticut Agricultural Experiment Station (CAES), and
Environmental and Human Health, Inc. (EHHI). These studies assessed organic
compounds, metals, and bacteria at various field systems to determine whether
exposure to contaminants may occur through direct contact (bacteria), off-gas
emissions, or stormwater runoff.
Organic Compounds
Various organic compounds have been identified to be associated with synthetic turf
materials. Volatile (and semi-volatile) organic compounds (VOCs and SVOCs) are
emitted as gases from certain solids or liquids. VOCs include a variety of chemicals, some
of which may have short- and long-term adverse health effects. VOCs can cause
irritation, and some are recognized as carcinogens or toxicants. The theory tested in
several reports is that these compounds may be released from synthetic turf systems
using crumb rubber infill during hot summer months and create harmful fumes (EHHI
2007). The types of compounds and concentrations were dependent on field conditions
(indoors or outdoors), testing setting (laboratory or natural setting), and types of materials
used, specifically infill materials. In general, these studies concluded that even the fields
using crumb rubber were found to have no significant health risks, as summarized below.
The OEHHA study conducted a literature review of several reports and performed air
sampling in four towns. Nine VOCs from a target list of 94 chemicals were detected in at
least two of eight air samples collected above an artificial field. Six of these VOCs were
also detected over natural turf fields. According to the OEHHA (2010), all exposures to
VOCs detected were below health-based screening levels, suggesting that adverse
health effects were unlikely to occur in persons using artificial turf.

i.b: Los Prados Park Turf Conversion Project (PA 14-105)

page.text: The Connecticut Department of Public Health (CDPH) (2010) prepared the Human
Health Risk Assessment of Artificial Turf Fields Based Upon Results from Five Fields in
Connecticut. In addition, the University of Connecticut Health Center (UCHC) (2010)
prepared the Artificial Turf Field Investigation in Connecticut: Final Report. Both reports
analyzed the potential of crumb rubber to off-gas. The CDPH developed a list of 27
chemicals of potential concern for the use of indoor and outdoor synthetic turf fields and
conducted a risk assessment for both children and adults. According to the CDPH and
the UCHC, benzothiazole, a rubber-related SVOC, was the constituent most likely to
volatize. The CDPH determined that the concentration decreased 20 to 80 percent after
pre-weathering for approximately ten weeks. The CDPH concluded that the use of
outdoor synthetic turf fields was not associated with elevated health risks.
The Connecticut Agricultural Experiment Station (CAES) study analyzed 17 alternative infill
materials (infill materials analyzed were not specified) that were not derived from crumb
rubber. The VOCs detected in the headspace over the virgin alternative infill materials
were different and fewer in number compared to those observed for the crumb rubber
infill material (CAES 2010). The compounds found in the headspace of the alternative infill
material were limited to xylenes and styrenes. The study also performed a leach analysis
of organic compounds, but it was limited to concentrations generated from crumb
rubber infill.
The Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) conducted an artificial
turf study in 2009 to analyze stormwater and leachate characteristics at four artificial turf
fields using crumb rubber infill materials. Upon scientifically evaluating the laboratory
analysis results of samples taken at each field, the DEP developed an environmental risk
assessment. Based on the results and comparison with previous studies, the report did not
identify any organic compounds at sufficient concentrations to be considered a
potential contamination risk to surface water or groundwater resources (DEP 2010).
A comprehensive 2008 literature review of over 100 studies conducted for the New York
City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene evaluated the off-gassing of crumb
rubber, ethylene propylene diene monomer (EPDM), and thermoplastic elastomers (TPE)
infill materials (TRC 2008). This intensive literature review focused on the potential
exposure and health effects related to synthetic turf fields. According to this review,
emissions of chemicals of potential concern were determined to be non-detectable or
similar to background levels. In addition, based on conservative estimates of exposure to
polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, volatile organic compounds, and particulate matter,
no significant risks to human health were identified.
With the conversion from natural turf to artificial turf, there would be a reduction in
pesticide and herbicide use on the Athletic Field.
Metals
Elements such as mercury, chromium, cadmium, arsenic, lead, nickel, copper, and zinc
are metals. Some living organisms require small amount of metals for survival (such as
copper and zinc); however, excessive levels can be damaging. The primary risk of
exposure to metals is through contamination of drinking water resources. Materials that
contain these elements may leach heavy metals into the environment under certain
conditions (through stormwater runoff, for example), conveying pollutants to
downstream surface water resources that serve as potable drinking water supply or
aquatic habitats. Heavy metals can damage living things at low concentrations and

i.b: Los Prados Park Turf Conversion Project (PA 14-105)

page.text: tend to accumulate in the body or in the food chain. Some metals, such as mercury and
lead, can also pose inhalation exposure hazards.
The primary method of exposure to metals from the proposed project would be through
leaching of metals from the crumb rubber material, which would be an environmental
risk, not a human health risk. During a storm event, there is the potential for small amounts
of heavy metals within the synthetic turf materials to leach into stormwater runoff and
downstream surface water resources. The CAES study analyzed the potential for metals
to leach from crumb rubber infill materials in a laboratory setting. Acids were used to
extract metals from the infill materials, which identified the presence of arsenic, barium,
cadmium, chromium, copper, lead, manganese, nickel, and zinc. Zinc extracted from
the crumb rubber samples exceeded the other elements by two to six times, dominating
the results. These findings support the theory that zinc, as an element of concern
associated with synthetic field systems, originates primarily from the crumb rubber type of
infill. The DEP (2010) analyzed stormwater and leachate characteristics at artificial turf
fields using crumb rubber infill materials to provide a comparison with the laboratory
results of the CAES study. A total of eight runoff samples were collected from three fields
using crumb rubber infill material. The DEP study found that the artificial turf fields using
crumb rubber infill materials leached significantly fewer contaminants, specifically zinc
and copper, than predicted by the CAES study laboratory results for crumb rubber infill.
These findings support the fact that the laboratory testing, which is designed to extract
metals, results in much more concentrated levels than “field” testing of water runoff.
After an analysis of all samples, the DEP study concluded that concentrations of zinc in
runoff from fields using crumb rubber infill exceeded the State of Connecticut’s acute
aquatic toxicity criteria and the surface water protection criteria established by the
Regulations of Connecticut State Agencies Surface-Water Protection Criteria for
Substances in Ground Water. The DEP study found the potential for impacts on
groundwater, however, to be minimal. The DEP study noted that the levels of zinc in its
study were similar to levels found in urban stormwater and suggested that the same best
management practices used for removing zinc from urban stormwater may also reduce
zinc concentrations levels generated by synthetic turf fields below the acute aquatic
toxicity criteria (DEP 2010).
A study in 2009 investigated zinc in drainage water under artificial turf fields with crumb
rubber infill. The study reported that in seven years of monitoring, there was no evidence
of zinc penetrating the underlay material and leaching. The study noted that such results
were consistent with laboratory tests in which it was calculated that zinc leaching will not
occur until a period of 230 to 1,800 years has elapsed. It was also suggested that the
concentrations of zinc in the drainage water were not significantly higher than the
concentrations in rainwater (Hofstra 2009).
In early October 2014, the Synthetic Turf Council (STC) issued a press release in response
to a nationally televised news story about synthetic turf. In that press release, the STC
stated:

text.i: The STC believes that reliable scientific data should be the foundation of any discussion
regarding the safety of synthetic turf with crumb rubber infill. During the past two decades,
there have been more than 60 technical studies and reports that review the health effects
of crumb rubber as it pertains to toxicities from inhalation, ingestion and dermal contact,
as well as cancer. These studies and reports were performed during the past 22 years by
independent organizations such as: Connecticut Department of Health, Hofstra University,
New York State Department of Environmental Conservation, The New York City
